Graphical abstract A novel integrated system PTC-TEG-PCM was proposed and designed for photothermal catalytic hydrogen production and 24-hour continuous thermoelectric conversion, which increased overall energy conversion efficiency by 500%. Solar-driven photocatalytic water/seawater splitting holds great potential for green hydrogen production. However, the practical application is hindered by the relatively low conversion efficiency resulting from the inadequate utilization of solar spectrum with significant waste in the form of heat. Moreover, current equipment struggles to maintain all-day operation subjected to the lack of light during nighttime. Herein, a novel hybrid system integrating photothermal catalytic (PTC) reactor, thermoelectric generator (TEG), and phase change materials (PCM) was proposed and designed (named as PTC-TEG-PCM) to address these challenges and enable simultaneous overall seawater splitting and 24-hour power generation. The PTC system effectively maintains in an optimal temperature range to maximize photothermal-assisted photocatalytic hydrogen production. The TEG component recycles the low-grade waste heat for power generation, complementing the shortcoming of photocatalytic conversion and achieving cascade utilization of full-spectrum solar energy. Furthermore, exceptional thermal storage capability of PCM allow for the conversion of released heat into electricity during nighttime, contributing significantly to the overall power output and enabling PTC-TEG-PCM to operate for more than 12 h under the actual condition. Compared to traditional PTC system, the overall energy conversion efficiency of the PTC-TEG-PCM system can be increased by ∼500%, while maintaining the solar-to-hydrogen efficiency. The advancement of this novel system demonstrated that recycling waste heat from the PTC system and utilizing heat absorption/release capability of PCM for thermoelectric application are effective strategies to improve solar energy conversion. With flexible parameter designing, PTC-TEG-PCM can be applied in various scenarios, offering high efficiency, stability, and sustainability. Keywords Hybrid solar energy conversion system Photocatalytic overall seawater splitting Thermoelectric power generation Phase change materials All-day operation 1 Introduction Renewable energy production is significant for the advancement of human society, since the overreliance on fossil energy leads to severe energy shortage and environmental pollution [1,2]. Hydrogen, as a promising secondary energy carrier, offers a green, clean, and high energy-density solution that can be derived from renewable sources to address the above issues. Solar-driven photocatalytic overall water/seawater splitting for hydrogen production has emerged as a viable and potential technological approach attracting extensive research attention over the past few decades [3,4]. Generally, photocatalytic materials must fulfill the requirements of sufficient band gap (>1.23 eV), as well as suitable conduction and valence band locations straddling the redox potential of proton reduction and water oxidation [5]. Various materials, including oxides [6,7], SrTiO3 [8,9], sulphides [10–13], polymers [14–16], nitrides [17–19], and so on, have been extensively studied for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. However, the current efficiency of solar-to-hydrogen (STH) by photocatalysis remains significantly below the threshold (10%) for practical application [20]. The limited STH can be ascribed to two aspects related to the principle of photocatalysis, which are the spectral distribution of solar energy and the structure characteristics of photocatalysts. Regarding the spectral distribution, solar energy spans a range of wavelength from 300 to 2500 nm, comprising ∼4% ultraviolet, 44% visible light, and 52% infrared light [21], in which the low-energy photons in long-wavelength region are unable to excite electron-hole pairs. As for the structure characteristics of photocatalysts, due to the fixed band gap, electron-hole pairs excited by the high-energy photons will relax to the band edge [22], with part of the photogenerated carries undergoing recombination in the process [23]. In fact, the majority of energy in the solar full spectrum is present in low-energy photons, which can be absorbed by reaction system (including catalysts and solution) and converted into heat to accelerate chemical reaction [24,25]. Besides, the thermalization of photogenerated carries can also provide thermal energy to reaction system. However, in spite of the introduction of heat enhancing the photocatalytic reaction for many systems [26–28], the STH is still limited by the bandgap and carrier separation characteristics of the catalyst, and most of the thermal energy eventually dissipated into the environment and was wasted. Furthermore, even for narrow-bandgap catalysts with ideal apparent quantum yield (AQY), there are still substantial amounts of thermal energy that cannot be converted and utilized since photocatalysis is driven by light rather than heat. Therefore, it could be an efficient way to increase overall energy conversion efficiency by rationally utilizing this low-grade waste heat. In addition to facilitating photocatalytic/photoelectrocatalytic reactions, the low-grade waste heat can be recovered by thermoelectric generator (TEG) and converted into electricity [29–31]. However, there was still significant room for improvement in the optimization of waste heat recovery in photocatalytic systems via TEG for power generation. Firstly, previous reaction system often contained sacrificial agents, and the activity of hydrogen production increased gradually with rising temperature [32,33]. However, the higher power efficiency could be obtained with larger temperature difference for TEG [34]. These two factors will bring about a conflicting outcome, as the enhancement of heat transfer for higher power output could result in a reduction of photocatalytic hydrogen production. Secondly, particulate suspension system is typically not conducive to the recycling of waste heat and requires the use of flexible TEG, which have complex configurations and large contact thermal resistances, leading to challenges in harnessing the full potential of thermoelectric materials [35,36]. Thirdly, solar-driven system generally cannot maintain 24-hour operation without sufficient heat storage capacity. Addressing the above drawbacks could enhance the overall energy conversion efficiency and provide a reliable technological pathway for efficient solar conversion. There are some feasible measures to solve these problems and perfect the system. One is to utilize an overall water splitting reaction with an optimal temperature range for photothermal catalytic (PTC) system [37], in which photothermal catalysis and TEG operation will be independent of each other. Furthermore, the reactor type can be modified as immobilized particulate system instead of powder suspension system, facilitating the arrangement of efficient rigid TEG [38,39]. Lastly, heat dissipation on the cold-side of TEG can be recycled using suitable heat storage materials, such as phase change materials (PCM), which can release heat in the dark for continuous electricity generation [40,41]. Herein, a novel hybrid system was proposed and designed to achieve simultaneous photocatalytic overall water/seawater splitting for hydrogen production and all-day thermoelectric power generation, which was denoted as PTC-TEG-PCM (Scheme 1 ). The design principle of PTC-TEG-PCM follows the concept of cascade utilization of energy. In this system, high-energy photons (hν ≥ E g) are utilized to excite photocatalysts, enabling overall water/seawater splitting. The thermalization of photogenerated carries and infrared absorption of the low-energy photons contribute to both boosting photocatalytic reaction and serving as heat source for TEG module. The TEG module can recycle the low-grade waste heat to generate electricity. Moreover, the low-temperature PCM is incorporated as heat sink for absorption of the excess heat in the daytime and as heat source releasing the stored heat in the nighttime for driving TEG module, providing a feasible method for realizing all-day power generation. By effectively harnessing the full spectrum of solar energy, the PTC-TEG-PCM system promises several advantages, including photothermal catalysis, efficient recovery of waste heat, and thermal energy storage, which can significantly improve the overall energy conversion efficiency and offer a reliable technological pathway for the cascade utilization of solar energy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetrabutyl orthotitanate (C16H36O4Ti, 98.0%, CP), ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, 99.5%, CP), strontium nitrate (Sr(NO3)2, 99.5%, AR), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 96.0%, AR), aluminium oxide (Al2O3, AR), strontium chloride hexahydrate (SrCl2·6H2O, 99.5%, AR), potassium chromate (K2CrO4, 99.0%, CP), sodium hexachlororhodate (III) (Na3RhCl6, AR), cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O, 99.0%, AR), and anhydrous ethanol (CH3CH2OH, 99.8%, AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Reagent Company in China. All of the reagents were used without further purification. Ultrapure water with a resistivity of 18.2 MΩ was used in all the experiments. 2.2 Methods 2.2.1 Synthesis of Al-doped STO (Al:STO) Al:SrTiO3 was synthesized by previously reported [42,43]. The details can be found in Supplementary Information Note S1. 2.2.2 Cocatalyst loading Cocatalysts were loaded by photodeposition [44]. Firstly, 0.1 g Al:SrTiO3, 0.6 wt% Rh3+ (Na3RhCl6), and 80 mL deionized water were ultrasonically dispersed and poured into a 105 mL special glass reactor. After purged with Ar for 10 min to eliminate air, the dispersion was irradiated by a 300 W Xenon arc lamp at 35 °C for 10 min under continuous stirring. Then, 1 wt% Cr6+ (K2CrO4) was injected into the reactor and then continuously illuminated for 10 min. After, 1 wt% Co2+ (CoCl2) was added into the reactor and illuminated for another 10 min. Subsequently, the sample was washed with deionized water and then dried overnight at 60 °C. Finally, the sample was placed in a tube furnace and calcined at 400 °C for 3 h under N2 atmosphere, and the heating rate is 5 °C min−1. The obtained sample was denoted as Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO. 2.2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a PANalytical X’Pert Pro MPD diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA using Ni-filtered Cu K α irradiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectra of the samples and solution were determined with a Hitachi U-4100 UV-vis-near infrared (IR) spectrophotometer equipped with a laboratory sphere diffuse reflectance accessory. The crystallite morphologic micrograph was determined on a JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope (TEM) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB Xi+ instrument with a monochromatized Al K α line source (400 W). All binding energies were referenced to the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. The light intensity of the Xenon lamp is tested with an optical power meter (PL-MW2000 Optical power meter). Temperature was measured by a thermocouple thermometer (TES-1310 K-type thermometer). 2.2.4 Evaluation of photocatalytic performance The details can be found in Supplementary Information Note S2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Design principle of PTC-TEG-PCM The novel PTC-TEG-PCM system consists of three main components, which are a PTC system for hydrogen evolution, a TEG module for power generation, and a heat storage unit for heat absorption in the daytime followed by heat release in the nighttime. There are two operational modes for the hybrid system including lighting mode during daytime and dark mode during nighttime (Fig. 1 ). The photocatalytic reactor is plate type made by polyether-ether-ketone (PEEK), quartz glass, and titanium plate (Fig. S1). TEG module (TEG-241-1.4-1.2) is rigid which was made of ceramic and Bi2Te3 with good thermal conductivity. The PCM tank was made by stainless steel and wrapped with thermal insulation cotton to reduce heat loss. A home-made copper fins are placed in the tank and used to enhance heat transfer. For the lighting mode during daytime (Fig. 1a), the PTC reactor, TEG module, and PCM container are closely placed from top to bottom. Incident light absorbed by solution and catalysts was converted into chemical energy and thermal energy. Waste heat is transferred to the top surface (hot side) of TEG through titanium plate, and finally transferred to PCM by the bottom surface (cold side) of TEG. The direction of heat flow is from top to bottom, driving the TEG to generate electricity while heating the PCM for thermal storage. For the dark mode during nighttime (Fig. 1b), because PTC system cannot function in the absence of light, the heat sink (cold source) instead of the PTC reactor is placed on the upper surface of the TEG module. The stored heat by PCM is transferred from the bottom surface (hot side) to the top surface (cold side) of the TEG, and eventually dissipated in heat sink. In contrast to the lighting mode, the direction of heat flow is from bottom to top, and the heated PCM performs heat release to drive the TEG for power generation. In a nutshell, the working principle of PTC-TEG-PCM is as follows. During daytime, PTC-TEG-PCM can produce hydrogen from seawater by photothermal catalysis, which utilizes the full spectrum of solar energy. The low-grade waste heat in PTC system can be recovered by TEG, converted into electricity, and partially absorbed by PCM. During nighttime, the released heat from PCM can drive TEG for power generation to achieve all-day operation. 3.2 PTC system for hydrogen production At present, only few catalysts have been reported to be capable for photocatalytic overall water/seawater splitting [45–47]. Al-doped SrTiO3 (STO) is a classic and commonly used material, which can achieve ∼100% AQY under ultraviolet light [44,48]. Here, STO was chosen as the catalysts for overall seawater splitting in PTC system. Rh@CrO x core-shell structure and CoO y were used as the cocatalyst for hydrogen and oxygen production, respectively. In order to improve the stability, after loading cocatalysts, the sample was calcined under N2 atmosphere, and the finally obtained sample was denoted as Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO. TEM image of Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO (Fig. 2 a) shows that cocatalysts were uniformly loaded on the surface of STO. High resolution TEM(HRTEM) image demonstrated that the Rh@CrO x core-shell structure was successfully synthesized, and the fringes with a lattice spacing of 0.22 nm could be indexed to the (111) planes of metallic Rh (Fig. 2b). Besides, the lattice fringes of Co3O4 also can be observed (Fig. 2c). Because the cocatalysts completely covered the STO, it is difficult to find the lattice fringes of STO in Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO. As a result, the sample loaded with only Rh@CrO x (Rh@CrO x -STO) was used for observation of microstructure (Fig. S2). It can clearly observe the lattice spacing with a distance of 0.276 nm which is well indexed to the (110) plane of STO (Fig. S2b). Powder XRD (PXRD) was used to determine the crystal structure of catalyst (Fig. 2d). Compared with STO, no variation in peak positions was observed in XRD patterns of Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO, which is consistent with a standard SrTiO3 cubic phase structure (JCPDS: 00-005-0634). No notable diffraction peaks of Rh, CrO x , and CoO y could be observed for Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO, which might accrue from its low content and weak crystallinity [49,50]. The compositions and chemical states of Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO were further investigated by XPS. The survey scan XPS spectra showed that Ti, Sr, O, Rh, Cr, Co, and absorbed C elements were detected, illustrating that cocatalysts were successfully loaded onto STO (Fig. S3). The high resolution XPS spectra revealed the surface chemical states of obtained sample (Fig. S4), whose results are consistent with the lattice fringes observed in TEM images, confirming the state of each element accurately in Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO. UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra characterized the light absorption of materials and seawater (Fig. 2e). It is shown that catalysts can only absorb the ultraviolet light and part of visible light, while the infrared light over 1100 nm can be perfectly absorbed by seawater solution (Fig. S5). After loading cocatalysts, Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO had higher absorbance than pristine STO in the visible region (Fig. S6a), but the optical bandgap did not change (Fig. S6b). The above absorption characteristics offered prerequisite condition for the design and operation of the PTC-TEG-PCM. Since the reaction solution was seawater, it is necessary to determine the products of photocatalysis. It is shown that the stoichiometric ratio of hydrogen and oxygen in the gas products was conformed to 2:1 (Fig. S7), demonstrating that the chloride gas was not produced during seawater splitting here. The hydrogen and oxygen production rates shown in Fig. 2(f) increased with the increase of reaction temperature in the lower temperature range (<45 °C), and then remained stable when the temperature exceeded 45 °C, illustrating that there is an optimal temperature range (45–100 °C) for the PTC system used in this work. This is beneficial for the PTC-TEG-PCM system since the increasing output of TEG by enhanced heat transfer would scarcely affect PTC system if temperature of reaction system was controlled within the optimal range. 3.3 TEG module for power generation A 55 × 55 mm2 commercial TEG was used as TEG module in the hybrid system. The output performance of TEG was measured on a home-built platform (Fig. S8 and Note S3). The cold-side of TEG was cooled by circulating cooling water for forced cooling (Fig. S8a) or ambient air for natural cooling (Fig. S8b). Here, the ΔT refers to the temperature difference between heat source and heat sink (Fig. 3 a). Since the existence of thermal resistance, the actual temperature difference of thermoelectric legs (ΔT ab), which determines the output of the thermoelectric device, is generally lower than ΔT [31,51]. It is shown that the output voltage and power of TEG with forced cooling (Fig. 3b and c) were much higher than those of TEG with natural cooling (Fig. 3d and e) under the same ΔT, illustrating that different heat transfer conditions have a great influence on thermal resistance and ultimately affect the output of TEG device. In order to increase the output of TEG in PTC-TEG-PCM, hot-side and cold-side of TEG should be in close contact with heat source and heat sink, respectively, and employ forced cooling rather than natural cooling in dark mode to enhance heat transfer. 3.4 PCM for thermal storage The low-temperature paraffin was used as PCM in the proposed PTC-TEG-PCM system for heat storage. A certain quantity of PCM was placed in a custom-made stainless-steel tank which was insulated with thermal insulation cotton. Both the output power of TEG and the thermal-storage capability of PCM in the integrated system under different operational conditions were tested by a home-built platform (Fig. S9). There are two operational modes including the lighting mode and the dark mode for PTC-TEG-PCM, corresponding to the heating process and cooling process of PCM. In fact, the performance of TEG and PCM relates only to thermal energy. Therefore, a thermostatic heating plate replaced PTC reactor was used to offer heat source in heating process (Fig. S9a); a water cooler (Fig. S9b) and an aluminum fins (Fig. S9c) were used as heat sink in cooling process to simulate different cooling conditions. In order to accurately detect the temperature of PCM, three temperature test points were arranged from top to bottom [52] (Fig. 3f). The phase-transition temperature of the PCM was determined to be ∼28 °C, as shown in Fig. 3(g). When the PCM was completely melted in heating process, the heat release can sustain for ∼8 h under forced water cooling at 20 °C. During the heating process, output voltage of TEG gradually decreased (Fig. 3h), because the temperature of PCM gradually increased resulting in an increment in the temperature of the cold-side of TEG. In comparison, during cooling process, the direction of voltage was reversed on account of the exchanged direction of heat flow resulting from the reversed cold-side and hot-side of TEG. Meanwhile, output voltage value of TEG remained unchanged during phase transition of PCM under the same cooling condition. The temperatures (T 1, T 2, and T 3) of PCM were detected to precisely reflect its state (Fig. S10). T 1 can approximately reflect the trend of temperature change of the bottom surface of TEG, but the value of T 1 was lower than the latter in heating process and higher than the latter in cooling process due to the existence of thermal resistance. T 2 is a referenced intermediate temperature for the spatially distributed temperature gradient. T 3 can indicate the state of the PCM, that is, when T 3 is higher than melting point, it can be roughly considered that PCM has completed phase transition. Since the thermal storage of PCM was constant, the duration of heat release of PCM became shorter when heat transfer was enhanced (Fig. S11a), but the output voltage was increased (Fig. S11b). Correspondingly, the PCM temperature (T 1, T 2, and T 3) was shown in Fig. S11. Importantly, it is shown that the heat release can continue over 20 h under natural cooling, which endows PTC-TEG-PCM with the ability for all-day electricity generation. 3.5 Proof-of-concept of PTC-TEG-PCM To evaluate the proof-of-concept of the as-proposed hybrid system, a prototype device was designed and assembled for simultaneous PTC overall seawater splitting and low-grade waste-heat recovery by TEG coupled with PCM to achieve all-day thermoelectric electricity generation. In the lighting mode during daytime, PTC-TEG-PCM was assembled by a PTC reactor with Rh@CrO x /CoO y -STO and seawater, a TEG module, and a tank filled with low-temperature paraffin (Fig. 4 a), as shown in the physical photograph of Fig. S12(a). It was used for PTC hydrogen evolution and power generation coupled with heat absorption of PCM. In the dark mode during nighttime, the PTC reactor was replaced by a heat sink with 20 °C circulating cooling water to enhance heat transfer and reduce thermal resistance between the cold-side of TEG and cooling source, which could increase the output power of the device driven by heat release of PCM (Fig. 4b and Fig. S12b). To verify the advantages of the hybrid PTC-TEG-PCM system, a referenced device retaining only the PTC portion without the TEG module and PCM (marked as PTC without TEG) was designed for comparison. Since PTC without TEG has no power generation and heat storage capability, it can only work in the presence of light, that is, it only operates in the lighting mode during daytime. When irradiated by a Xenon lamp in the laboratory, the reaction solution temperature (T R) in the referenced device PTC without TEG was higher than that in PTC-TEG-PCM under the same light intensity (Fig. 4c). It is shown that the system temperature gradually increased and basically reached the equilibrium state in 0.5 h light irradiation. In order to exclude the effect of ambient temperature (T 0), the temperature difference between seawater and environment was recorded (Fig. S13), which shows that the temperature raise in PTC without TEG was also higher than that of PTC-TEG-PCM, illustrating that heat transfer capability from the bottom of PTC reactor to PCM by conduction in PTC-TEG-PCM was greater than that to environment by convection and radiation in PTC without TEG. Although the reaction temperature in PTC-TEG-PCM is lower, hydrogen production was hardly decreased compared with PTC without TEG (Fig. 4d and Fig. S14), since the balanced temperature of reaction solution in both PTC-TEG-PCM and PTC without TEG was in the optimal temperature range (>45 °C). For this reaction system in the optimal temperature range, hydrogen production rate was related mainly to light intensity while scarcely to temperature. In addition to PTC overall seawater splitting for hydrogen production, PTC-TEG-PCM hybrid system can recycle the low-grade waste heat to generate electricity by TEG and achieve all-day operation by PCM with thermal storage via heat absorption and heat release. The output voltage of PTC-TEG-PCM in the lighting mode can reach about 0.404, 0.634, and 0.790 V after 0.5 h under the light irradiation of 500, 1000, 1300 mW cm−2, respectively, and gradually decreased to 0.391, 0.557, 0.714 V in 3 h (Fig. 4e). Meanwhile, temperature of PCM gradually increased along with waste heat storage (Fig. S15). After switching to the dark mode (light off), PCM began to release heat toward heat sink (20 °C cooling water) for driving TEG. In this process, temperature of PCM dropped rapidly to the phase transition point (28 °C), subsequently was kept at 28 °C for a period of time until the PCM turned from a liquid to a solid, and later gradually decreased and approached the cold-source temperature (Fig. S15). The tested voltage of TEG was maintained at about −0.369 V during solidification of PCM, and the greater the light intensity in lighting mode was, the longer the stable output time in dark mode, which is attributed to the fact that PCM could not be completely melted at lower light intensity (Fig. 4e). Additionally, the tendency of corresponding output short-circuit current was consistent with output voltage (Fig. S16). Temperature difference between heat source and heat sink could reflect the changing trend of ΔT ab (Fig. S17), which determines the output performance of TEG. The hybrid PTC-TEG-PCM system offers an advantage of maintaining a stable phase transition temperature range in either lighting mode or dark mode, ensuring a relatively steady output from TEG. It is worth noting that there was some fluctuation for both PCM temperature and output of TEG in dark mode, since cooling water flow rate could affect the heat transfer and further influence output performance of TEG (Fig. S18). Therefore, the cooling water flow rate should be kept as constant to reasonably compare the performance of PTC-TEG-PCM under different conditions. Next, the output characteristic of PTC-TEG-PCM was evaluated. Output power of TEG in the whole process including lighting mode and dark mode was calculated based on measured voltage (Fig. 5 a and Note S4). It is shown that the output power of TEG in the lighting mode can reach 8.14, 20.13, and 31.20 mW after 0.5 h under the light irradiation of 500, 1000, and 1300 mW cm−2, respectively, and eventually reduced to 7.64, 15.51, and 25.48 mW when the light turned off. In the dark mode, output power of TEG was the same and approximately 6.8 mW during the phase transition of PCM as a result of the identical cooling condition (Fig. 5b). The accumulated electricity of PTC-TEG-PCM in an entire operating cycle including lighting mode and dark mode was 138.53, 263.80, and 387.7 J under the light irradiation of 500, 1000, and 1300 mW cm−2, respectively (Fig. 5c), and the corresponding output electric energy in the dark mode accounted for 43%, 30%, and 25% of the total electricity (Fig. 5d), which were considerable percentages benefiting from the advancement of PTC-TEG-PCM mainly in thermal storage of PCM. The energy conversion efficiency was calculated to evaluate the advancement of the PTC-TEG-PCM system (Note S5). The overall energy conversion efficiency benefits from the contribution of two parts, which are efficiency of solar to hydrogen and efficiency of solar to electricity. Hydrogen is produced in PTC system and electricity is obtained from TEG module. For PTC-TEG-PCM, the overall energy conversion efficiency is the sum of solar-to-hydrogen efficiency and solar-to-electricity efficiency. However, for PTC without TEG which only produces hydrogen, the overall energy conversion efficiency is equal to the efficiency of solar to hydrogen. The calculated results showed that the overall energy conversion efficiency of PTC-TEG-PCM could achieved 0.249%, 0.239%, and 0.267% under the light irradiation of 500, 1000, and 1300 mW cm−2, respectively, which are much higher than 0.049%, 0.047%, and 0.046% of the referenced device PTC without TEG that only produces hydrogen and wastes a lot of heat (Fig. 5e). It can be considered that a ∼500% improvement of overall energy conversion efficiency was achieved by cascade utilization of full-spectrum solar energy. In PTC-TEG-PCM system, the efficiency of solar to hydrogen was 0.045%, 0.045%, and 0.048% under the light irradiation of 500, 1000, and 1300 mW cm−2, respectively, and the corresponding efficiency of solar to electricity reached 0.204%, 0.194%, and 0.219%, respectively (Fig. 5f). It can be found that whether in PTC without TEG or in PTC-TEG-PCM, the efficiency of solar to hydrogen barely changes, demonstrating that the improved efficiency of PTC-TEG-PCM is attributed to the recovered waste heat by TEG for power generation. Besides, another referenced device based on a previous reported technological route was designed for comparison [31], that is, utilizing natural cooling for both lighting mode and dark mode and using the thermal self-storage capacity of reaction solution instead of PCM to drive TEG in dark mode, which was named as PTC-TEG with natural cooling (Fig. S19). The results showed that the hydrogen production was 342.26 μmol in PTC-TEG with natural cooling under the light irradiation of 1300 mW cm−2, which is basically equivalent to that of PTC-TEG-PCM (Fig. S20a and b). Temperature of reaction solution in PTC-TEG with natural cooling was also almost the same as that of PTC-TEG-PCM (Fig. S20c). However, the output voltage of PTC-TEG with natural cooling in the lighting mode was lower than that of PTC-TEG-PCM, which is attributed to the higher cold-side temperature of TEG resulting from the larger thermal resistance using natural air cooling (Fig. S20d). It is also shown that PTC-TEG with natural cooling can operate about only 1 h with the light off and the accumulated electricity was negligible during this period (Fig. S20d and e), which is far less than PTC-TEG-PCM, indicating that the thermal storage of PCM can effectively solve the problem of insufficiently continuous output capacity during nighttime. Furthermore, overall energy conversion efficiency of PTC-TEG with natural cooling was 0.163%, lower than 0.267% of PTC-TEG-PCM, which was mainly ascribed to the lower efficiency of solar to electricity (Fig. S20f). The above results showed that the PCM can not only enhance heat transfer to improve output voltage of TEG during daytime, but also increase the working time and output electricity during nighttime via thermal storage. The stability of PTC-TEG-PCM was tested under light intensity of 1300 mW cm−2 in the lighting mode and with 20 °C circulating cooling water in the dark mode to simulate the entire working process during daytime and nighttime. The temperature difference between seawater (T R) and the surrounding environment (T 0) maintained a constant trend during the as-conducted five cycles (Fig. 6 a), so did T R and T 0 (Fig. S21a). Hydrogen and oxygen production could also remain more than 90% after five cycles (Fig. 6b and Fig. S21b). Moreover, output voltage of TEG and temperature of PCM including T 1, T 2 and T 3 also kept a steady trend of change (Fig. 6c and Fig. S21c). Above results indicated that the hybrid system PTC-TEG-PCM is durable and can realize long-term operation without significant performance degradation. To demonstrate the feasibility of all-day thermoelectric electricity generation in practical application, PTC-TEG-PCM was illuminated by Xenon lamp for 4 h under the light irradiation of 1300 mW cm−2 in the lighting mode during daytime and adopted natural cooling in the dark mode during nighttime to simulate all-day operation (Fig. 6d). After turning off the light, the heat release time of PCM can hold more than 12 h, where the temperature can be maintained at the phase transition point for about 8 h (Fig. 6e). Correspondingly, PTC-TEG-PCM can also keep generating power for over 12 h, where the output voltage of TEG was about −0.1 V during phase transition process of PCM (Fig. 6f), illustrating that it can continuously operate all-day benefiting from thermal storage of PCM. It is worth noting that the heat storage capacity of PCM depends on the amount of materials used, and hence it can be improved by increasing the dosage of PCM. Additionally, the specific designing parameters of PTC-TEG-PCM, including the area of light window, dimensions of PTC reactor, the specification and quantity of TEG, PCM dosage, etc., can be reasonably adjusted according to the conditions including light intensity, illumination time, and heat transfer mode in practical application. Moreover, the three components in PTC-TEG-PCM are interrelated in performance, but do not interfere with each other in terms of their function and application. The integrated system is not limited by specific reaction of (sea)water splitting, which can be extend to other similar application, such as carbon dioxide reduction, nitrogen fixation, and interfacial water evaporation. So long as there is low-grade waste heat produced in PTC system, PTC-TEG-PCM can operate with similar mode and achieve all-day thermoelectric conversion, which could enhance energy conversion efficiency, with corresponding parameters flexibly optimized and modified to meet specific practical working conditions and requirements. Lastly, the electricity generated by TEG module can be directly applied locally or stored in the batteries/supercapacitors for other utilization [53–57]. 4 Conclusions In this work, a hybrid PTC-TEG-PCM system was proposed and designed to achieve simultaneous photocatalytic overall seawater splitting and all-day thermoelectric power generation by integrating PTC reactor, TEG module, and low-temperature PCM. The entire solar spectrum can be utilized by PTC system to boost hydrogen evolution, along with recovering the waste heat by TEG module to generate electricity and storing excess heat by PCM. Subsequently, the stored heat in PCM is released to continuously drive TEG for power generation during nighttime, achieving a complete recycling of waste heat. Following the principle of cascade utilization of energy, PTC-TEG-PCM significantly improves the conversion efficiency of solar energy. Compared to a PTC system without TEG, PTC-TEG-PCM not only retains hydrogen production but also generates additional electricity. The electricity produced during the nighttime can reach a considerable proportion, resulting in the overall energy conversion efficiency improved by ∼500%. Furthermore, PTC-TEG-PCM can operate all-day under natural cooling condition during the nighttime. The design strategy and operational mode of PTC-TEG-PCM offer an effective and feasible technological pathway for solar energy utilization. coredata.dc:description: Solar-driven photocatalytic water/seawater splitting holds great potential for green hydrogen production. However, the practical application is hindered by the relatively low conversion efficiency resulting from the inadequate utilization of solar spectrum with significant waste in the form of heat. Moreover, current equipment struggles to maintain all-day operation subjected to the lack of light during nighttime. Herein, a novel hybrid system integrating photothermal catalytic (PTC) reactor, thermoelectric generator (TEG), and phase change materials (PCM) was proposed and designed (named as PTC-TEG-PCM) to address these challenges and enable simultaneous overall seawater splitting and 24-hour power generation. The PTC system effectively maintains in an optimal temperature range to maximize photothermal-assisted photocatalytic hydrogen production. The TEG component recycles the low-grade waste heat for power generation, complementing the shortcoming of photocatalytic conversion and achieving cascade utilization of full-spectrum solar energy. Furthermore, exceptional thermal storage capability of PCM allow for the conversion of released heat into electricity during nighttime, contributing significantly to the overall power output and enabling PTC-TEG-PCM to operate for more than 12 h under the actual condition. Compared to traditional PTC system, the overall energy conversion efficiency of the PTC-TEG-PCM system can be increased by ∼500%, while maintaining the solar-to-hydrogen efficiency. The advancement of this novel system demonstrated that recycling waste heat from the PTC system and utilizing heat absorption/release capability of PCM for thermoelectric application are effective strategies to improve solar energy conversion. With flexible parameter designing, PTC-TEG-PCM can be applied in various scenarios, offering high efficiency, stability, and sustainability.
